places.name: Lainaston
places.description: Untraced.

places.name: London Institution
places.description: The London Institution was founded in 1806. Francis Baring (1740–1810), a wealthy banker, was an instigator of the London Institution and became its first President.

places.name: Axbridge
places.description: Possibly the small town of Axbridge in Somerset.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: Pluto
persons.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: René JustHaüy
persons.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

places.name: Rowley Hills
places.description: A range of hills in the West Midlands, England.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: Cnut
persons.description: King of England, Denmark and Norway between 1016 and 1035. At Bosham, alledgedly ordered the tide to reverse.

persons.name: HenryPemberton
persons.description: An English physician and man of letters, who edited the third edition of Isaac Newton's Principia Mathematica. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacBarrow
persons.description: First Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge University. Isaac Newton was his student. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: Cambridge
places.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
persons.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: LadyC.
persons.description: Untraced, probably the wife of Charles-Louis Cadet.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Prometheus
persons.description: In Greek mythology, defied the Olympian gods by stealing fire and giving it to humans.

persons.name: UlisseAldrovandi
persons.description: Italian naturalist and father of natural history according to Buffon and Linneaus.

persons.name: CarlLinnaeus
persons.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

persons.name: SamuelJohnson
persons.description: Johnson was a poet, novelist, essayist, playwright and lexicographer.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: UlisseAldrovandi
persons.description: Italian naturalist and father of natural history according to Buffon and Linneaus.

persons.name: Theophrastus
persons.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: Pliny
persons.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: SlareFrederick
persons.description: Physician and chemist who worked for Robert Boyle. FRSL.

persons.name: SchweitzerJohann Friedrich
persons.description: Dutch physician and alchemical writer, usually known as Helvetius.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: GalileoGalilei
persons.description: Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: MissSlater
persons.description: Dates untraced. Female subscriber at Royal Institution, full details untraced.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Mrs S.Turner
persons.description: Dates untraced. Female subscriber at Royal Institution, full details untraced.

places.description: A county in south-west England.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasWebster
persons.description: Assisted lecturers at the RI, including making transparencies use in Davy's courses of lectures on geology.

persons.name: ThomasBernard
persons.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

persons.name: CharlesRoyce
persons.description: Assisted Royal Institution lecturers, including Davy, bewteen 1802 and 1808.

persons.name: GeorgeShaw
persons.description: Assistant Keeper and then Keeper of natural history at the British Museum. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

persons.name: Pliny
persons.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: Jean-ClaudeDelamétherie
persons.description: French mineralogist and naturalist.

persons.name: Eugene Louis MelchiorPatrin
persons.description: French mineralogist and naturalist.

persons.name: GregoryWatt
persons.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.

persons.name: RobertJameson
persons.description: Scottish geologist and Regius Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh. FRSL.

persons.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
persons.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

persons.name: Johann JakobScheuchzer
persons.description: Swiss geologist and palaeontologist within a Biblical context. He was a diluvialist and believed that rock strata and fossils were deposited during the Great Flood. His account of the supposed remains of a human who witnessed the flood (Homo Diluvii Testis) was published in Latin in 1726. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Antonio-LazzaroMoro
persons.description: Italian abbot, naturalist and geologist.

places.name: River Tees
places.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: GregoryWatt
persons.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.

persons.name: Johann GottlobLehmann
persons.description: German mineralogist and geologist.

persons.name: AthanasiusKircher
persons.description: Prolific German Jesuit scholar and polymath who published many book, including on geology.

persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

persons.name: DenisPapin
persons.description: French-born assistant in the Royal Society of London. Developed an early form of the steam engine. FRSL.

places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesWatt
persons.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

persons.name: GregoryWatt
persons.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.
